reviewText:
I saw this film last night at a special screening. It's mindboggling, but thoroughly enjoyable. It's probably best enjoyed if you have a background in science or engineering, but I think that's more a of a cultural background than a plot essential.

I'll try to keep spoilers to a minimum. The story concerns the friendship of two young engineers (Abe and Aaron) living your average suburban life. In their spare time, they dream of creating the next big thing in Aaron's garage. They eventually stumble on to something of immense possibilities, but are unsure of what to do with it. As they begin to exploit the possibilities of their new invention, a rift begins to develop in their friendship.

This film will probably require multiple viewings to figure out exacly what's going on. Many people thought that they ending was bizarre, but it does follow logically if you pick up the clues. The strength of this film is in the two main characters. It's a character-driven plot that happens to be set in a science-fiction story. However, the science is an important part of the film as well. The sci-fi bit is one that's been covered in numerous films and books, but Primer covers it more carefully than any other story I've seen. The science in the film is vague enough to be plausible, which is how sci-fi should be. Too many movies go over the top in their explanations, leaving those in the audience with a technical background laughing out loud.

I saw this movie at the end of technology convention in Lake Tahoe, NV.  I found this movie to be completely hard to follow and understand.  I would highly recommend people going to see this movie at least 2 times.  The movie completely skips around a lot.  The movie is a science-fiction movie about two people who create a time machine and put it in a storage locker.  This movie boarder-lines on a "Back To The Future" wanna-be movie; in that you shouldn't interfere with yourself in the past.
Great Movie :)
I liked the part when he traveled through time that one time. I disliked the part when he traveled through time that other time.

This is one of those thinking movies. Think Inception, but with a more complicated plot-line. I've seen it ~5 times and I kind-of know what happened. It was made really cheaply, like a few thousand dollars or something equally ridiculously-low. If you're looking for fancy Hollywood stuff, look somewhere else. The beginning is kind of slow, but if you have faith and keep watching, you'll be rewarded.
Wish I could time-travel back to before I saw this overrated garbage.

It opened strong and had promise but gets way, way too confusing and doesn't stop to explain anything.  Very frustrating.  Had to google the Wiki page while watching.  Nobody seems to understand what is happening in this movie.  The science is irrelevant, it's impossible to figure out what is happening with the main characters and what the hell is going on all of the time after about half way through the movie.

This review is for the standard DVD of 'Primer' released by New Line Home Video in 2005.

This movie is about as polarizing as it gets. I suspect that most people will either love it or hate it. For that reason I'm averaging it out and giving it 3 stars.

For the record, I did not like it. It is way too confusing and requires way too much thought for not nearly enough pay off. Also, for the record I am a big science fiction fan.

This movie not only requires a lot of thinking, it requires you to do it fast. There is no time to think about what is going on. Therefore, unless you are a total genius, you must rewind parts, sometimes several times. Even then, I have to admit, I didn't really get it. I had to go and read up on it to truly understand what is going on.

RECOMMENDATIONS/CONCLUSIONS: If you are a hardcore science fiction fan who has a lot of knowledge of science, physics in particular, then you will probably love this movie. If you are not well versed in the sciences, then you will most likely hate this movie and probably not watch it till the finish. Once you get lost early on, you have to make the choice to rewind and watch again or just give up.

Kudos to the film makers who did this on such a tiny budget and were willing to take a chance on making a movie that falls well outside the norm.
Its a great movie. I recommend
okay movie
Watched it a few times. Needed web reviews to understand it
The story is conceptually strong, but the film is hamstrung by incoherent storytelling, a poor script (with random voiceovers), and amateur community theatre acting. Meh.
Great Movie. Need to watch 2 or 3 times.

Forget about the plot - everyone talks about the plot - and remember for a moment that everyone here is an actor. All of the interactions feel wholly naturally, and the environments and situations these men and women find themselves in are realistic and candid, without the forced grit or awkward nature of other movies. This is just a really excellent science fiction film super imposed upon a really excellent, relate-able drama.

It can be fun to try and follow along, watch it again, dream about the sequence of events, or whether or not the sequence is fixed, linear, or even relevant, and what the implications of that might be, but definitely don't forget to stop and appreciate that everyone there is just playing a role, and that they're doing it beautifully.
The most excellent representation of possible time travel. Fully enjoyed.
Low budget but well-written and thought-provoking!  Doesn't tackle the big time travelling 'what-if' scenarios but is still very interesting and the science seems plausible.

My first thought in the opening scenes: "Where did they find an actor with such true intelligence in the face?". Only at the end I found out it was the script writer/director himself, who, by the way, used to be a software engineer - ha-ha, no wonder! Overall thoughts after seeing the entire film: 1) Interesting, atypical approach to time travel, 2) By look/feel, this is the most realistic sci-fi I've ever seen, which is achieved not through amateur camera work (camera work was actually pretty good) and not through high-tech special effects but through very natural acting, as well as very realistic technology used in the scenes and surroundings (very average looking houses, streets, roads, etc.). 3) The film holds your interest throughout the entire length even though it's very modest visually and relies a lot on the dialogue, 4) It gives you pleasure in a way similar to a puzzle, it teases your brain, provokes thoughts. Piece of advice - pay attention to the names of the people and the types of relationships between them - you will not see these relationships unfold on screen but will find out about them from dialogues of the main characters. This will give you the clues to what actually happened in detail. I am bad with remembering people's names and did not pay much attention to description of people's situations in the dialogues and came to regret it. I got what happened at a high-level (like, I am sure, most people) but need to watch a second time now to write down names and relationships to understand more detail.
Confusing.  And I did enjoy Momento.

5 Stars, maybe for everybody, but not for every mood.

If you're into Sci Fi and looking to unwind with something exciting, with good pacing, clear character motives and developments that make immediate sense... Check out Project Almanac, Looper, or Edge of Tomorrow. All fantastic films with unique takes on Time Travel.

Save this movie for a time when you're rested, or at least ready to focus and invest some brain power into a dense and layered story. It's more of a old-fashioned foray into Sci Fi. More like something that a modern Jules Verne or H.G. Wells might write. Dense and nuanced with lots of explanation of rules and big words that you may or may not understand without a dictionary.

If you're ready, this is a great film worth more than one watch. It's sure to be a cult classic both for it's technical execution as well as the questions it raises about morality.
Intentionally confusing pseudo science, the target audience is shallow 15-25 year olds.
The movie was a little slow paced, but more a decent time travel story. It was a little hard to follow at times without taking some time to think about what was happening.

When major sci-fi buffs have to spend forty minutes after the film just trying to work out the basic plot arc, that's not "edgy and avant garde storytelling," that's just bad writing. When at the end of 40 minutes, no one agrees on that basic plot arc, that's a poorly created film that really botched what seems like it could have been a good concept.

Hard to follow, I believe this is a film one gains a better understanding of after watching it more than one time.  The concept is brilliant, however the writer, director, editor were so close to the project that they misjudged how much information should be given to the audience. I hate the term dumping it down as I think this film draws an intelligent viewer and I don't want to insult myself or other viewers, but I had to watch it twice before getting a basic grip on the overlaying time travel storylines.

Too much quasi-imaginary techno speak dominating the film, not enough basic exposition on the main themes. The low budget sound quality made trying to follow an often mumbled or muted (by background noise) story-line difficult, tiring, and annoying. I kept falling asleep, rewinding, and falling asleep again. It's worth a watch if you can overlook the budget restraints (uneven acting, uninventive location shooting, and film quality). That said, the reason to watch is the storyline: looping selves that question the strength of ones core morality with each iteration until the viewer is left with the idea that morality is a faux principle based only on one's current self interest.  I couldn't sit through it again due to the 1 star for the low-budget, school project feel of the production, stiff dialogue, and unnecessarily jumpy editing. It would definitely see it again if it were remade with a decent budget and if the dialogue were sharper.

As an engineer, this is a fantastic representation of the accidental discovery and abuse of time travel. However, I would note that the director A. Did not simplify jargon for the general public and b. Acted in the movie because any actors he found were to dramatic to represent an engineer. Do expect an intriguing movie, do not expect a high energy movie.
High price
Gives the impression that this was somebody's weekend project or a school assignment. Mumbling actors, complex and inexplicable plot line. Weird.
Definitely a cerebral thinker.  Pay attention or you'll lose track!

Frustrating to watch a film where the exposition was so absent that you unexpectedly get to the end of the film and have no clue what just happened. Add in flat acting, boring pacing and lackluster music (and a complete lack of any special effects whatsoever) and there you have it. I actually looked up some sites to help explain what the heck happened in this film, and even after reading those I still don't have any clue what was going on. This is a time-travel story without a cool Delorean but rather involving boring crates in a storage locker, with characters who you can't really associate with at all. I thought initially they might be heading towards a 'body horror' direction with multiple time-jumps but no, instead this film just meanders into a puzzling, dry conclusion that leaves you unsatisfied and mystified at the time wasted.

I suppose if you're into the cerebral side of analyzing time-travel paradoxes you might enjoy this, but budget plenty of time to try to work out the Gordian shoelace knot of this cinematic mess.
A must have.
Bizarre and interesting indie movie.
Clever movie that will test your ability to put the pieces together.

What an interesting concept.  But as the story developed, I got lost.  It was not clear when the scenes were set.  Perhaps someone with a better attention span and concentration could have understood the progression of events better than I.  I was curious enough to read the synopsis in Wikipedia to satisfy my need to know what I had missed.  My problem with the movie is that I want to be entertained and this movie was not entertaining.  I can't help but think that the story could have been told in a clearer presentation.  I give it two stars for a good story.
great movie

I read the mixed reviews -- some good, some bad. Then I tried to watch the movie. I think three times over the last few years. But, I could never get through it all the way. With one last effort, I tried again today ... and I only got through about half before I started skipping ahead to end my misery as quickly as possible. It's mainly the unlikable main characters always in their stereotypical white shirts and ties, with their token friend of color (who gets few lines or camera time) ... and their strained dialogue, always trying to sound overly conversational ... and especially all of the technological mumbo jumbo. It all makes for a really annoying experience. The filmmaking warts I can excuse from a low budget production like this, but the story, characters and dialogue have to make up for that. In this case, in my opinion, they do not. If you want to see what Shane Carruth is capable of as a writer/director, I suggest you pass on this "student effort" and go right to Upstream Color, which I really enjoyed.
Incredibly interesting and complex on such a shoes string budget
I had high hopes for this movie but it was mostly confusing... It was okay
Loved the film but... Why is this movie so expensive?

hard to follow, and a confusing ending.

A low budget film with an original & unique time travel story. This is the kind of film that shows you how you don't need millions of dollars to make a great film. So far this summer (2016) we have been subjected to too many 100+ million dollar duds. I'll take this film over those anytime.
Two young brainy guys accidentally create time travel in their garage & take it outside to experiment with. Watch them try to figure out step by step what they have & how to use it & deal with consequences.
Great movie, super plot
brilliant and creative and deep. love it!

This one was bad. Here's the fundamental problem. It's a story of very moderate complexity that is deliberately made a hundred times more complicated by deliberately being opaque, hoping we'll confuse opacity for profundity. It doesn't respect me, and that's why I can't respect it. I think a good rule (though one that might not win accolades) is that when the subject matter is complicated, it is all the more imperative that communicators (e.g. movie directors) make it as clear as possible to make up for the inherent complexity of the subject matter. These people did the opposite, and it doubtless convinced many more people that they were looking at a work of genius. I'm sad that's the kind of world I have to live in.

Primer is not a movie for everyone, but if you're so inclined, you will love it.  Two engineers build what turns out to be a time machine.  That's all I will give away, but I disagree with the reviews that talk about the stiffness of the characters or the dialogue or what a waste of their time this experience was.  I enjoyed every minute of it.  If you aren't an advanced mathematics super genius, just remember:  The characters themselves understand the premise and machinations, and by trusting the narrative flow, all will be revealed.  I found the interactions between the two main characters to be intelligent and non-sexually intimate.  Their individual intellect(s) function as a unit, and the stages of discovery, then conflict find them retaining that intellectual consistency, while growing more suspicious of each other's motives.  You cannot derive the full meaning of this film with one viewing.  Multiple viewings only make me want to watch one more time.  On a personal note, I have had several friends and acquaintances around this level of intelligence, and the single-minded obsessiveness of the characters is pitch perfect.  Also, the way time travel is portrayed is low tech, but compelling in its own right.  IF time travel turns out to be a possibility, it'll probably look more like this than "Looper," although that movie had its own charms.  Hope this helps.
It follows timelines fairly accurately, which will leave some people dazed for a short period after watching.

Too Complex. You can't talk technical about something that doesn't exist. The acting wasn't too bad for a 7k film. I was lost as soon as they are outside Uhaul watching Abe cart in the O2 tank. There is no timeline that makes sense, but overall a decent time travel film.
Awkward. Confusing. Boring. Other than that, I hated every lost minute I spent watching it.

This was a truly a mind bending exercise in time-travel. The first time you watch this, it will undoubtedly end in a "what just happened" moment. It starts out rather slow but picks up the pace later. There are multiple timelines occurring during the movie and it's certainly worth watching a second or third time through. It is so thoroughly complex that even the characters become lost in the uncertainty of events. This is a low-budget movie so don't expect any kind of special effects; this movie is for those that like trying to sift through a mystery to try and discover what happened and when.

I highly recommend reading the "The Definitive Graph of All of Primer's Intersecting Timelines" on io9's webpage but do this AFTER you watch the movie for the first time.
very cool concept and they made the impossible believable.  However, the lost me in the end.
Wasted $4 on this show. Not worth it! No action or excitement. Looks like drug junkies messing around.

As a Hollywood film, I'd give it a 3 star.  As a low budget indie pic - I'd give it a 4.  A bit slow in the beginning, and missing a few scenes (like where is the money you guys made?! - new cars or something - plot point not included.) but compared to most low budget indies, I can see why this is in the top 100 Sci Fi films with some good reviews... watch with an open mind...  it's tame compared to say "PI"  in B/W - now that movie will spin your head literally...
Loved it!
Too nerdy. The over-emphasis on tech aspects drowns out everything else. Carruth's other movie "Upstream Color" is really cool, but this one falls flat.

If you like technogeek, this is for you -- technogeek, where the tech takes center stage but the human characters are tragically stiff and offer no real reason to care about any of them.

Low budget, and it shows.

Wish I had a time travel machine so I could get this time back.

As much as this movie left me thinking pondering after it was over it was not in a good way. Points are given for making a hard to forget movie but these guys did it the wrong way. Throughout the film vital information required to understand what was going on was missing. Scenes were very discombobulated. It was consistently frustrating and by the end I really had little idea what was going on, how they managed to time travel, affect anything while hibernating in coffins, the significance of the party and who the guy in the hoodie near the end was, what he was doing or what significance his actions had at all. Most of the dialogue was quite cryptic.

I wouldn't recommend this film and I won't watch it again because i don't think there is enough content to ken much of anything form it. Two stars only because it unsettled me enough to want to read about it on the internet.
Amazing

Sadly, this movie disappointed from the opening scenes - poor quality sound, combined with almost continuous background noise (cars on the highway, computer fans) and multiple actors talking over each other made it impossible to follow the plot. The video quality was also lacking, but that's less of an issue, and is really to be expected in low budget movies like this.

The sad thing is that I kept hoping it would get better, or at least less confusing. But it didn't.

What's even worse is that having sat through this I thought I'd take a look on IMDB, and try and understand what had just happened. Looking at the plot synopsis, I think this could have a been a great movie - clearly an original idea, with the potential to be great ruined by budget constraints or, more likely, lack of experience... Perhaps one day this will be remade with the budget and expertise it deserves - and I'll take another go at it, but I won't be watching this again.
Excellent sci-fi movie.  Really makes you think and makes you want to watch it over again.  Blows your mind!

Let me first say that I love good sci-fi movies.  I also like thought-provoking movies that make you think.  So this movie would normally be right up my alley.  Unfortunately, its downfall is that it's just too confusing.

The concept of this movie is great.  I also love the fact that it takes an approach that feels very realistic.  The fact that it's a low-budget film, doesn't hurt it at all, in my view.  But I don't think it's ever a good idea to confuse the audience.  There's a difference between a complex plot, and a story that is disjointed.  To me, this movie feels disjointed.

There's a reason many people say that you have to watch this movie multiple times.  This is because the story is told in such a way that you're bound to become confused.  Very few details are ever explained, and you're left with an understanding that contains many gaps and holes.  It's like trying to put together a puzzle without being given all of the pieces.

I don't want to say anything about the plot because the best thing about this movie is the way that it leads you on a curious journey.  "Cube" is also like that.  The less you know, the better.  But unlike "Cube", which is written in such a way that you can completely follow the story, but still have a sense of exploration as you watch it, this movie gives too little detail about certain aspects.  This may have been on purpose, but it doesn't work well for me.

If you get lost watching this movie, that doesn't necessarily mean that you weren't paying attention.  I think the story is simply told with too few details for you to ever follow it with complete clarity -- even if you watch it more than once.  To me, this is bad story telling.  It's not that the story isn't good, or that it doesn't have a solid plot.  The plot and concept are great.  I even love the approach this movie takes by choosing not to simply spell everything out for you.  But I think they went a little too far with that, and, in the end, it's a bit frustrating.

If you like movies like "Cube" and "Memento", then you may have some appreciation for this movie.  It does a great job at feeding your curiosity.  Unfortunately, the story isn't told well enough to be as good as the other movies that I've mentioned.  "Primer" isn't a movie that I would choose to own, but it also wasn't a complete waste of time.  Had they done a better job telling the story, it could have been special.

It's hard to rate Primer.  I give it a strong grade for originality, creativity, and the ability to keep me interested.  But it's intentionally and excessively confusing to the point of being a major negative.  So overall - it is just ok.
Practically speaking, time travel is an enjoyable challenge to understand

Give this movie two stars for an innovative screenplay and some original ideas.

However, the creators do not get those last three stars because, although they tried, in the end they failed to put together a comprehensible story, and they also wrecked the two characters which they had initially made sympathetic but in the end turned into bad guys.

A frustrating experience.
Boring
Love this story.  It's a thinker.  You have to pay attention though, I had to see it twice.  Not an action movie, more of a what if.
I LOVE sci-fi, but this movie SUCKED! I watched the whole thing hoping it would get better. No deal. Don't waste your time.
Great concept; I've been going over it for weeks.  However, minus one star for the near-incomprehensible recording of the dialog.
Valiant effort on behalf of the filmmakers with such a small budget, but I'm sorry, I love avante guard stuff but this one made no sense

I stumbled across "Primer" by typing science fiction into a google search for a movie night. I was instantly intrigued when I watched the trailer. Suffice it to say that this movie contains almost no cliches and is fast paced and intriguing. I would recommend it.
Okay
Well done and thought provoking.  Watched it, read a synopsis, watched it again, read some more.  Might need to give it one more watch.  Ha ha
Are you kidding? It's a shame this movie has anything lower than 4 and a half stars. The best independent film since raging bull

Primer is tough to give three stars to; it feels like it ought to be more. It is very different and has upstart indie spirit. But IMO, Primer does not do enough of a job telling the story and leaves too much work to the viewers (a lot information is simply missing, as opposed to open to interpretation). If you enjoyed the TV series Lost, how it leaves things unexplained, then this probably will not bother you. For myself, I enjoyed both Primer and Lost, but at the same time felt dissatisfied. Nonetheless, if you are at all curious, I recommend it.

I was expecting more from this movie than what I got. It was frankly, hard to hear. All the characters mumbled and I wasn't always sure what was going on. There were some time-travel issues that weren't addressed - you can't have two of you at the same time in the same place, but hey, lots of time-travel movies struggle with that. There are virtually no women in this movie, which isn't a crime, obviously, but Hollywood's obsession with women used primarily as props, plot devices, or set-dressing gets me down after awhile. I found it interesting that they used vintage weebles for their experiments. Why would you hunt down a collectible toy on ebay just so you can destroy it? Lol, stupid thing for me to point out, I guess. Anyway, worth a watch, but I was not enamored with this film as much as other reviewers.
Mindbending, gritty. Not fun, but memorable.
I'm going to be watching this again. Incredibly confusing, not for the casual movie watcher.

Adding a caveat, I thought it was exceptional, for a low budget movie. I liked being challenged by the various idea modes in the theme. Stories of time travel will always lure the adventuresome and tickle the imagination of dreamers. That said, I hate it when the main thrust of a time travel movie relies totally on bursting through a worm hole. This movie is different. I enjoyed it.

Great movie about engineers gone haywire!

A friend of mine, engineer, told me about this movie and put off seeing it for a while...I am glad I finally watched it!  There is nothing technically accurate or mind expanding about the movie, it is just a great portrayal of how engineers, at least the one I know, behave and do their day to day scheming.  You can see it happening all the way through, they get caught up in the potential, they loose their discipline and things go sideways quickly!  This is not an action movie...it is a character study.  Do not take a date to this movie!  There is a decided lack of "chickness" about it.  I am pretty sure the only people who will appreciate it is other engineers.  Maybe have a beer when the family is out of town and watch because you just cut off the cable$$$$ and don't have any other quality entertainment....

I enjoy "difficult" or "challenging" movies, but this is simply bad storytelling. Failing (or refusing, if I want to give them the benefit of the doubt) to make the action more clear does a disservice to what could have been a great movie. But too many plot points hinge on characters and events that are never, or barely, shown on screen. Too much of the dialogue is obtuse to make any sense of.

I suggest that people who rave over this movie are experiencing a sort of Stockholm Syndrome. It's captured their imagination, and because they don't understand it and assume it to be of superior intelligence, they convince themselves that they love it. Well. I didn't love it, and I found its inability to communicate a narrative while posing as an authority condescending.
A good film.

The movie is about three stars the first time you watch it.

It becomes five stars when you immediately replay it and watch it a second time.
Still one of the best--if not THE best--time travel movies ever.

The movie has a very interesting premise. It is not a completely original idea (there have been some science fiction stories with very similar basic concept) about a sort of time travel through the creation of copies of one (or more) individuals. Unfortunately the movie script is quite hermetic. What is worse it seems to me that the director was purposefully obscure. Unless, which is also a distinct possibility, he is just clumsy as a director.

There is something about this film that is peculiarly well done. Something you know to be clearly impossible is put completely into the realm of believable experience in a way that I found to be extremely compelling. It's subtly spectacular.

Primer (2004)

 I think that no other time travel movie I have ever seen has the same compelling power of Primer.  This erudite, entertaining and baffling film resembles nothing that I have seen before, which  I like very much.  And now we know the name of Shane Carruth, the movie maker behind this arresting $7,000 movie.  Shane Carruth wrote, directed, produced and stars in this exceptional little film.  His friend David Sullivan co-stars.
 The two leads play a pair of long term friends, engineers, who with another couple of guys, are busy making things in their garage, doing good science and getting patents -all in support of a chance to make the big bucks.  Abe and Arron, the Sullivan and Carruth characters, in a side experiment, discover a way to send themselves backward in time-but only a few hours backward.  They quickly set up a secret time machine and begin to make serious money by using their fore knowledge of the stock market and other money generating events.
 What could possibly go wrong?
 We find out.  The plot has such opacity and murkneyness that I can not say I fully understand what went down, exactly.  But as a watcher I can say that I didn't turn away from the screen for a minute.  This may be best seen on DVD where the viewer can watch it several times to get the full effect.  In any case, this movie has a uniqueness and a vision that we have not seen in the genre before.
 Others like the film as well, not just me.  It garnered four awards from the Sundance Film Festival (2), the Nantucket Film Festival and the prestigious London International Festival of Science Fiction.  And producer Carruth got his and his friends money back to boot.  The box office rant to $425,000, a 60 to one return never mind the later DVD revenue.
 Primer runs a short one hour and 17 minutes and carries an "PG-13 rating.
 Carruth used Super 16mm film and locations around Dallas Texas in making the film.

Sometimes something comes along that is so different, it's a game change. Just as often something comes along that appears to change the game but, in reality, is just a mess. "Primer" is the latter.

"Primer" has a terrific concept for a movie buried in a film that has little to no narrative momentum, exposition that is so eliptical as to be virtually non-existant and makes more avant-garde films like "Hiroshima Mon Amour" to actually be an action movie. "Primer" provides a perfect example of how not to make a movie compelling, interesting or challenging. Some movies require concentration but, when you have a movie that requires a garmin to find the plot, that's not a good thing.

SPOILERS:

Abe(David Sullivan)and his engineering partner Aaron (Shane Carruth who also wrote an directed the film)have been working with their two friends to create new products in hope of finding that million dollar discovery. Abe comes up with a device that they think alters gravity. Instead, it's a time machine. The two decide that they are going to use it make millions by going back in time with stock tips. Needless to say, things don't turn out that way.

END OF SPOILERS

Where to start? "Primer" won lots of awards. It's unconventional narrative wowed some critics so much that they didn't realize the writer and director couldn't tell a story to save his life. The film is a mess with a story that borders on incoherence and that's not because the story is complex or beyond folks--it's because the filmmaking is so disorganized. The first hour moves at a glacial pace.

Is "Primer" a disaster? No just incomprehensible due to a poorly constructed story.
Had to take notes to understand all the traveling around.

This movie is in it's own class. Other reviewers have done impressive jobs here describing it so I won't add much.
A fascinating and also at times frightening look at the dangers of genius when not combined with morality.
Also provides an interesting look into how a group of talented scientists might work together to invent and build new technologies.

Proof again that great storytelling is more important than millions of dollars worth of explosions and CGI.
Hollywood please take notice.

For an independent Sci-Fi film decent somewhat thought provoking.  Likely you will see it  - then need to do a google search on it to have the movie explained.  I did and there are some good explanations out there.  w/o giving anything away it involves the complications involved in time travel.

The way I explain my appreciation of this movie is this:

You know how, when you are watching a movie and there this complex idea being explained by one very smart person to another very smart person, and although you have no trouble following it, the other very smart person always says, "What do you mean?" and the first very smart person then explains the same thing again but at an eighth grade level?  That drives me crazy sometimes.

I was watching this movie for the first time, and one person was explaining something to another in a way that was not easy to grasp.  As the scene went on, I realized, oh wait, they're not reexplaining it for me.  I had to rewind -- rewind, RIGHT!  Showing my age here -- I clicked back to the beginning of the chapter so that I could pay better attention to what they were saying, so that I could actually follow the conversation.

From that moment on, I was watching and listening to this movie with my full attention and with my brain turned "on".  Not many movies do that to me.

Primer is about Aaron and Abe. It starts out slowly as they mess around in a garage trying to build something while not building anything in particular. They stumble upon time travel, completely by accident, but they can only go back a few hours. From there things get sticky, convoluted, full of loops and tricky loopholes.

The film is written and directed by Carruth who also plays Aaron. It's low budget but somehow still unbelievably smart and engrossing. Now, there are a lot of smart films that have been made. Carruth goes a bit of a different route though because he does not hold the viewer's hand. At all. There are things that it would be very hard to figure out while watching the film. The film takes twists and turns and makes no attempt to keep you up to speed. That's up to you, the viewer. The only thing the film seems to work at in terms of the viewer is keeping your eyes glued to the screen because you know something big is happening and you want to know what the heck it is. The only films I've had to dig deeper into on the internet after watching them have been David Lynch films. Shane Carruth is like Lynch in a way, but Lynch if someone reined him in and kept him from being so in love with his own ideas.

This little film left me with some big questions about what I would do if I could rewind, what would I endure until I got things just right, and is that even possible. Theres something that feels creepy, malevolent, and just not right by the time you get to the end of the film. The characters have changed, their world has changed and not just for them. I felt almost haunted by the possibilities and the realities within the film.

Mile-a-minute science fiction revolving around the theory of time travel and the conceptual danger of a paradox effect. Though its production values are terribly low - the film was made for just $7,000 - Primer's discount visuals actually work well within the context of the story itself. Narrow in scale but not in scope, it hones in on a small team of overworked engineers who discover functional time travel by accident, then set about (naturally) exploiting it to solve their money troubles. The air of intensity and excitement is palpable, with an almost nonstop track of dialog running from start to finish, and that really gives the scene a sense of authenticity. True savants, these guys possess excessively bright minds, and clearly their mouths are struggling to keep up with the volume produced by their brains. It would be easy to get lost in the minutiae of what they're saying and miss the forest for the trees, were the discourse not so insanely fast and heavily loaded. We're dealing with a seriously complicated subject matter, after all, and not even the twin geniuses at its epicenter seem to fully grasp the particulars of what they're living through. Let's put it this way: this isn't the first time I've seen the movie, and I still had to look up a summary afterwards to work out a few of the details. Distinct, intriguing and baffling complex, it's tough to watch without a furrowed brow and the nagging understanding that you're the dumbest person in the room. Open this puzzle box at your own risk - once it's out, there's no putting it back.

It's worth a watch. The film's concept is intriguing and Carruth's
mechanism of time travel is fresh and original. However, the execution
of this film is so sloppy and the plot so tangled, that it renders the

Yes, the sound is a nuisance. There is no proper sound engineer for
this film (considering it was made on such an ultra-low budget), that
it's difficult to truly follow most of the conversations the first time
through. Particularly outside the storage facility when Abe first
introduces Aaron to the possibility of time travel. That was the
moment when the plot started to gain momentum, and it wasn't
impactful in the slightest.

It's not just the sound. It's the pacing. Which I understand is meant
to be a bit muddled in places. But there are many plot points and
questions brought up that aren't even answered adequately or even
remotely touched to be meaningful:

**SPOILER ALERT**

1) Why Rachel's dad would collapse / be comatose as a result of time
travel, when this effect doesn't happen to either Abe or Aaron. And
their reaction to his comatose state is quickly glossed over. It
doesn't even seem to be a motivating factor for the course of the plot,
even though it obviously changes their perception on the safety of what
they're doing. Since this character never talks, you don't even get a
reason for why he would have discovered the box (let alone get inside)
in the first place.

2) The degeneration of their handwriting. I mean, Abe even asks Aaron
at one point why they can't write. Specifically asks. And is given no
answer. Why would they even bring this up? Is this a visual to convey
the literal degeneration of their lives and wellbeing as a result of
time travel? Does this handwriting issue have anything to do with
Aaron's bleeding? It just doesn't go far enough to matter.

3) Attending the party in multiple permutations to "save" Rachel.
Firstly, Abe and Aaron don't go to the first party. They hear about it
from their two fellow entrepreneurs. What possesses them to
return to the past to "correct" the events of this party where no one
gets hurt? It didn't seem to have any meaningful impact before... and
yet, after the comatose state of Rachel's dad, this party comes to the
forefront again. I don't understand the connection. I've heard that
Aaron wanted to be a hero, but no where do we come to understand how
this fits in with what we've seen of his overall motivations. The
character development regarding Rachel, or even the relationship she
has with Abe, is so ignored and minuscule, that this relationship means
nothing to me.

So in general, I find the editing, pacing, and visual quality of this
film to be muddled and these issues dampen what could have been a
genre-defining moment for this otherwise fresh film.

In a non-descript storage facility in the suburbs sit two mysterious machines, the culmination of a group of friends hard work, of their nights, of their weekends, of as much capital as they could muster. Then they discover something shocking, theyve created time machines.

The question of what do with these machines arises. At first it seems the machines may be commercially valuable, but this proves false. This is when the inventors turn towards using the machines to benefit themselves.

One inventor is conscientious from the beginning, while the other inventor is more adventurous. One inventor is wary of the potential dangers while the other inventor ignores them. They both profess their not wanting to alter the past, but each has a different level of commitment to the subject. They both try to keep the project quiet, under wraps from world, but things easily get out of control amongst themselves. Aghast at their errors, they try to set things right, but since time travel functions according unknown sets of laws different from those of linear time, the concocted logical solutions to their problem end up becoming just additional steps towards disaster.

As a sci-fi thriller this film works very well.

Primer is the most realistic science fiction movie I've ever seen, and hands down the best time travel movie of all time! Many time travel stories depend on invoking either nostalgia for long-passed days or dystopian fear of distant futures. Still others depend on far-fetched occurrences and/or special effects to achieve their goal. Primer, on the other hand, is in a class all its own. To begin with, the time travel destinations are only hours or days removed from the present. This is part of what gives the film its very puzzling quality, as people do not age noticeably nor do environments change drastically within a few days time span. As a result of this, the chronology of the film must be deduced primarily from the behavior, intentions, and dialogue of the characters; behavior which is unpredictable, intentions which evolve as the film moves along, and dialogue which is awesomely scientific. As other reviewers have pointed out, the writer/director/protagonist/composer makes no attempt to dumb down the conceptual framework and overall temporal complexity within which the film operates. Primer is difficult to understand. Whether you are a scientist or a science fiction fan, the first time you watch it you will probably only fully comprehend about half of it. But this, for me, is the film's best quality. The urge to rewatch it is immediate due to the fascination invoked by what was not comprehended. At this point I have watched it several times, and each time it makes more sense to me, however I still do not fully comprehend it.

Difficulties aside, Primer is a beautiful film with top-notch cinematography and an amazing score. It is very refreshing to see a science fiction film without the standard barrage of computer-generation and overly-dramatic music. Any "special effects" experienced are the result of very well-thought-out shots combined with skillful editing. The music is well-placed, optimistically melancholy, and at the same time invokes an undeniable sense of wonder and possibility. The acting is down-to-earth and believable. The characters portrayed are not superhuman and do not have unlimited resources. The feeling that you get from the film is that you have become a witness to actual extraordinary events. In my opinion there is no other science fiction film (time travel or otherwise) that accomplishes this feat as well as Primer.

Storyline you ask? Normally, I'd preface this type of review with a bold "SPOILER ALERT", but I suspect those who've yet to see this film couldn't make sense of the spoilers anyway. I'm not sure one can really "spoil" such a convoluted plot even if they tried.

I'd like to give this film 5-stars for its originality and a very creative concept in the best tradition of Arthur C. Clarke (as noted is a few other reviews), but a lot of that creativity was lost on a plot that became too obtuse and burdensome for its own good -- which is why I have to give it a 1-star.  I like films that are intellectually challenging but prefer not to have my brain fried during the experience. And that's the quandary I had with "Primer", it was too smart and too film-school artsy for it's own good; it's one ripping science fiction yarn that kinda went off into the film festival weeds with way more abstraction than what was needed to tell a relatively simple, but good, story.

The main stumbling block for me:  the plot could've been greatly simplified without losing its appeal. The audience really deserves a few more clues and guideposts along the way to make the cinematic journey that much more enjoyable without sacrificing artistic creativity or the intended meaning of the film. As any good writer knows, stay out of the way of a good idea and let the words flow naturally -- don't embellish, don't add unnecessary artifices for the sake of appearing "artistic"!

On the plus-side, I enjoyed the style and texture of the film from a geeky-person's point of view; the scripting was so natural I thought I was watching a historical documentary. No CGI, no special effects of any kind (although that levitation machine they build in their garage was kind of cool). You don't need a lot of zap-bang-boom-pow effects, battling mega-robots, mindless car chases with somersaulting SUV's, naked body-doubles performing simulated sex to keep people's attention when you have a GOOD STORY to tell!

On the minus side: the plot had WAY TOO MANY versions of Aaron, Abe, boxes and fail-safe boxes to keep track of without the aid of a spreadsheet. What the story lacked was just enough continuity to hold the plot together long enough for people to figure out what was going on. I eventually figured out most of it -- except for the the final scene in the "warehouse". Frankly, I think there were points in the film where the writer/director/actor wasn't entirely sure what was going on.

It seems clear to me (after multiple viewings) that the "beginning" of the film really wasn't the beginning at all given that the first rendition of Abe was, in fact, a time traveler who made the first trip in the machine and traveled back six hours to inform his partner, Aaron (sitting on the park bench) that the trip was successful. He proved it buy taking Aaron to the storage facility where we see the "original" Abe returning to the machine after leaving the hotel.  After that, things got real complicated to the point where we have not one but THREE Aarons running around -- "hoodie" Aaron, "original" Aaron locked up in an attic and rendition #2 Aaron.  Now add in another version of Abe to the mix along with two "fail safe" machines and you have a real mess.  Oh, and don't forget, these time machines are portable -- you can fold one up and take with you back to the past.  Enough, already!!!!!!

Which brings us to the brief final scene: one of the Aarons splits from one of the Abe's at the airport and ends up in this big warehouse directing some sort of activity, presumably building a larger version of the time machine. Many commentators & reviewers saw no special significance in this scene, but I thought it was a rather odd way to end the movie, especially given the low budget -- why shoot unnecessary footage?  And what was with the French-speaking dude directing that crowd of hard-hatted works in the warehouse?

I now believe the entire movie was intended to depict a corrupted time line from the get-go and the Aaron we saw in the warehouse was, in fact, the original Aaron (as opposed to the Aaron locked in the attic).  If you have a better idea, please let me know.
This film is quite simply the best film about time travel that has ever been made or (likely) ever will be made.  You should definitely watch it.

Why is it that as soon as a DVD goes temporarily out of print, those with copies to sell raise the price anywhere from 400-1000%? Previously, I bought two copies of this DVD from Amazon for about $10 each. After watching it several times, I gave them to friends as gifts. I logged onto Amazon today to buy another copy (for myself) only to find that the opportunistic profiteers are now asking anywhere from $40 to over $100 for it. As one might suspect, this leads to a lose-lose situation. I lose the ability (or at least the willingness) to buy and enjoy this DVD, and they lose the sale.
  With that said, Primer is a wonderful movie about the discovery of the technology to enable time travel. I have no doubt that if the ability to travel through time is ever discovered, that discovery will take place exactly as portrayed in this film. Written from a fly on the wall standpoint, anyone who has read Hackers by Stan Levy, or is familiar with the early days of Apple Computers (when Steve Jobs was still working out of his garage) will feel dj vu all over again ;) Everything is so believable it's scary. It's the reality that wasn't (or was it?).
  Admittedly, it's the type of movie that best appeals to fans of "hard science" fiction. There are no special effects, no wisecracking aliens, no supernatural forces... just a technology beyond our present level of understanding. There is little character development, but this is a film about concepts - not about characters. I didn't find this movie extremely difficult to follow or understand, but be prepared to pay attention. This is not the type of film to watch while eating dinner, or minding the kids.

I like a challenge, but this is one of the most confusing movies of all time. Despite its brevity, looping plot, and highfalutin physics dialogue, Primer (2004) still comes away a winner in my book.

I am not sure if this movie's circularity actually makes sense. Really. (Chuck Klosterman is said to have seen it seven or eight times and is still not sure what transpired.) The basic premise is that a group of four dudes accidentally invent a time machine in a garage while spending their spare time after their day jobs working on computer hardware. Aaron, the married guy with the garage, and Abe, his single friend, decide to keep the discovery a secret from the two other dudes.

If only they could keep the secret from their past selves (or is it future selves?).  Abe decides to fashion a desk-sized version of their first television-sized time travel box. And this is where the movie gets really interesting, raising all kinds of philosophical and existential issues along the way about time and space, morality, and reality.

I don't want to give too much away, but let's just say that Abe and Aaron start to travel through time. Like any red-blooded American males that have moved beyond college and into the working world, the guys predictably use time travel schemes to boost their financial situations. They exploit the stock market. But, things become less than kosher and fancy free when trust breaks down between Abe and Aaron.

The final 15 minutes of this movie are a head-scratcher. There is so much looping and nefarious backstabbing going on between Abe, Aaron, and their "time doubles" that I could not follow it. Wikipedia has a nice diagram that explains the time travel device and how it works; I can't understand that, either. I walked away feeling that the creator of this movie is very intelligent, but not in a way that allows him to leave the average viewer (i.e., me) walking away feeling victorious for figuring out the M.C. Escher maze that was laid out. Good luck.

I am a fan of short movies, and at 78 minutes Primer is a miracle of efficiency. But, the pithiness of the film was a product of necessity and a small bankroll, so it is possible that my gripes about the last 15 minutes might have been lessened if the director/actor/writer/producer/cameraman in charge of this picture had more film stock to work with. Just another 10 minutes might have relaxed the breakneck pace and confusing looping in the last 15 minutes.

One of the most incredible aspects of this film is that it was produced on a $7,000 budget, most of it dedicated to film stock. In the first five to 10 minutes of action, you'll note that the cinematography and sound are not up to big studio snuff. The dialogue seems to overlap, and the acting is wooden. After the time machine is discovered and the plot really kicks into gear, the brilliant story takes over and you forget about the amateur, low-budget feel. You relate to the protagonists, placing yourself into their shoes and considering the implications of the "fun" that time travel could provide before the complications rear their ugly heads. The middle of this movie is the satisfying thought-provoker, the beginning the underwhelming physics lesson, and the ending a mystifying quagmire.

Primer works if you go in with a little knowledge of the plot, have already slogged through movies like Memento and Inception, and bring your patience "A" game. And don't do this one alone. The real fun with a movie like Primer is discussing it with your friends and family afterwards.

Most bizarre movie I've seen in a long time. I was told it was done with an extraordinarily low budget, but it doesn't seem like it. A group of four engineers are working on something in the garage of one of their homes, and I must say it is not obvious what they were planning to create. What they got started out being some sort of super-efficient energy source, so that may be what was intended. But what they ended up with was a time machine. Not like the H.G. Wells type that takes you forward or backward to a specified time. It's more like the time turner that Hermione Granger used in Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban. Of course, there are paradoxes to avoid, but that's no problem. They just look up what stock has increased in value the most, then go into the time reversal machine (stored in a storage bin they rented), and when they come out, go buy a bunch of that stock.

The real problem comes when they get word that a former boyfriend of one of their friends came into a party and started shooting. Of course they want to go back and change things so nobody gets hurt.

If you can follow the permutations of the action, and realize which "edition" of the two men who are moving through time you see at a given time, you're more clever than I am. I think I'd have to see it several more times to get it all straight.

It's a mind-blower, an amazingly clever plot, and my hats are off to these guys for a very good movie on what was allegedly about $7,000 budget. I got bogged down in the science, but trust that it was plausibly done. It all sounds plausible, at least as much so as those science fiction stories I used to read all those years ago.

"Primer" might be the greatest inside joke on audiences since the 1938 radio broadcast of "War of the Worlds".  It was meant to be confusing and subject to multiple interpretations.  There is a relatively restricted voice over narration which breaks with film convention by being unreliable, adding yet another layer of vagueness to the story.  "Primer"  requires engaged viewers to give free reign to their imaginations, and since the commercial films these viewers have been consuming are too structured for multiple interpretation, the novelty causes some of them to proclaim it a work of considerable genius.

Indeed its subject matter, the perils and paradoxes of time travel set in motion by an inexplicable amoral character (Aaron - versions one, two, and three) with futile fixes by an equally inexplicable moral character (Abe - versions one and two), present quite a cerebral challenge to a viewer seeking such a challenge.  Unfortunately all this is at the expense of concurrent suspense or on-screen entertainment value; there is plenty of fun to be had with this film, but the enjoyment comes retrospectively after the initial viewing.

In "Primer" time travel is only possible to the past where the traveler must mark time in real hours before a return to the present, the time machine cannot be used to leap forward into the future.  And one can only travel back to the point at which the time machine first existed (there must be a time machine in the past from which a person can emerge).  It presents time travel as a process where causality does not affect the time traveler.  Making it the flip side of "Back to the Future",  whose premise was the peril to Marty McFly's existence should he alter the events that led to his being born.  "Primer's" time travelers can alter past events and thereby change the future, but the corporeal form that time traveled to the past is immune from the consequences of their actions;  thus any number of the same person can exist simultaneously.

The film itself is a poorly told narrative whose assorted deficiencies (be they deliberate, necessary economies, or just general laziness) are disguised behind a smokescreen of non-unified, noncontiguous representations of space and time (literally and figuratively); with segments and timelines full of jump cuts and inserts that fracture the sequencing.  If you listen to the commentaries on the DVD you will find that pre-production was an afterthought and that those associated with the film were generally clueless during its ultra-cheap production phase.

Everything happened in post-production, where the motivation was not to assemble the best told version of the story with the material they had shot; but rather a desperate and inventive effort to create enough confusion and ambiguity that the staggering lameness of the actual production would be adequately obscured.  Watch for several occasions where a single segment is cut and the visual pieces re-assembled in a different order, while the audio track plays in its original order.

Thus you have a modern day "Emperor's New Clothes", a film that exploits the conceit of its most enthusiastic viewer segment.  Rather than appear to be rubes these viewers attribute the confusion to the genius of writer/director/star Shane Carruth.  Even taking it so far as to disparage those who do not enthusiastically embrace the film (note the negative votes for earlier reviews that do not 100% embrace the film - people hate to have it pointed out that they have been duped by a crowd mentality). To be fair, judging from the DVD commentaries no one associated with the film appears to have taken the thing very seriously, or to be terribly taken with themselves, or to be affecting (at least at the time they were taped) any Orsen Welles pretensions.

Patrick McGoohan had a similar experience with "The Prisoner", a television series that explored deeper subject matter than your standard secret agent show.  A cult developed around the series, attributing intentional symbolism, metaphor, allegory, and philosophical substance to every word, gesture, and production design element.  Although unlike "Primer", "The Prisoner" was a top quality production that had some profound things to say,  just not to the degree its cult following wants to believe.

I continue to enjoy repeat viewings of "Primer" and continued speculations about the ramifications of what it presents.  But for the actual exercise of reading a film with a scrambled timeline, I prefer something like "The Life Before Her Eyes" (2007);  where the timelines are also fractured and a fair about of expressionistic elements are inserted, but  all done by design in the service of inventively telling the story and better communicating the themes.

Then again, what do I know?  I'm only a child.

I seldom review movies, but felt compelled to review this one. This movie is a special gem.

I also seldom buy movies, but I bought this for myself and all my engineer/math/computer scientist friends. This movie is so subtle yet so insidious. And yes, I had to watch it at least 3 times before I began to fully realize how complex it was. Watching it is a recursive experience in itself. Each time something new is illuminated. I will not give away the content, but if you think there are only a couple timelines in here and only two people... you are missing most of the movie. There are many more levels, permutations, and acting parties, all embedded, so in effect you are watching the culmination of potentially an infinite number altered originals. In fact, the entire movie plot may just be one permutation among many alternates. The last minute of the movie made me rethink the entire premise once again and forced me to re-watch it again.... and just as before I walked away realizing that there was more to the story than before. (A sick part of me thinks this would be a great movie to give as a weird form of am IQ exam. To see which people can identify how many number of timelines in it after watching the movie only once... I would probably not fare too well)

The fact that the movie lacks almost all exposition (except for the brief phone message voice over) makes this a story you must watch with a clear head and an attention to detail. The details in the movie are everything. I would like to say that this rivals David Lynch, except that David Lynch has never made a coherent movie that was in fact logically flawless. There are no mistakes here, blatant contradictions, deus ex machina resolutions, or weird ambiguities for the sake of weirdness. This movie feels like it was written by either a mathematician or a logician. It is simply put, flawless in design and conception. A part of me is extremely jealous. I could go on about the low budget, the dedication of everyone involved in the production, but that would miss the entire point of this movie.

Regardless of the production or anything related to it, the movie, on its own stands for as a the benchmark against which all other time-travel, multiverse, etc. movies will have to be judged against. It is one of my top 3 movies of all time. Inception was fun, but only had 3 or so plausible alternative explanations. This here has... well enough to make Godel chuckle. I defy anyone to tell me of another time travel movie that is more consistent in its recursive M.C. Escher-esque beauty.

For those who gave this movie 1 star, you probably didn't quite get something. I recommend you do any of the following (1) watch it again and realize you are watching a movie about recursive time travel, (2) read up about the concept of recursion, and (3) if you're still lost look up the detailed chart available online that shows all the timelines and how they are intertwined.

Others have explained here the basic plot of PRIMER: how two young engineers, while working on another project, accidentally create a time machine.  Their seemingly innocuous trips through time create dark consequences and rifts in their relationship, things neither of them had ever expected to happen.  The film is not at all linear to a "normal" person's perspective, and most people will have to watch the movie a few times (or search for an explanation online) before they will even begin to figure out what really happened.  It is a low-budget thriller with excellent scriptwriting and actors that portray very realistic reactions to the emotional chaos that they realize they are creating all around them.  I enjoyed the film very much--especially once I understood it.

I was one of those people who had to look online to see what had really happened.  I saw the movie, an anniversary present from last year that had been forgotten and unwatched for too long, this past week by myself while my husband was at work.  I found it suspenseful and intriguing, and knew immediately when I was 'missing' something, but of course I was too confused to even begin to understand what I had misunderstood.  When my husband came home that night, and I told him I finally watched it, he essentially whined, "Will I love it or will I hate it?"  Not for this review to be about us, but my husband is one of the most logical and emotionally detached yet irritable individuals I've ever met (think a cynical Mr. Spock from STAR TREK).  So I essentially just arranged for last night, Friday, to be a date night where we watched it together...

Little surprise, my husband understood IT ALL in one go, but I was more curious if he liked it or not (he did).  We sat on the couch afterward and I fired question after question at him, and he explained everything to me, I really was kind of proud of him!  But it amazed me how differently people's minds work, and it made me realize how so many people just couldn't understand PRIMER in one viewing because their thought processes are too linear, the cut-up fashion of the movie's action leaves so much more unsaid than ever shown.  Either way, it is a thinking person's movie, and I wouldn't expect everyone to like it or have the patience to watch it x times over to understand it.  Yet even though I was personally one of those people who needed help to understand it, I found it to be a great sci-fi thriller even with my initial confusion.

Primer is certainly one of the more challenging movies I've seen in a while. Shane Carruth, the director and one of the main actors, gets a lot right, particularly the atmospherics and dialogue. Unfortunately, the film almost seems too focused on these aspects, but leaves viewers confused about the plot. It's an odd film, but one definitely worth checking out if you like thoughtful, cerebral sci-fi. Oddly enough, for a sci-fi movie about time travel, Primer's treatment of science is easily one of the film's strengths. This is no H.G. Wells' The Time Machine, where time travel simply involves a machine with lots of lights and gadgets. Rather, the time machine in Primer is a much more sophisticated affair. At least the first 20-30 minutes show Carruth and David Sullivan's characters discussing the science behind the machine and sharing the audience's surprise at the discovery of time travel. This stems from Carruth's astute understanding that many key scientific breakthroughs happen through serendipity, not dramatic eureka moments. Sure, much of it is techno-babble, but it's probably the most convincing depiction of a time machine and time travel ever in cinematic history. Unfortunately, the techno-babble at the beginning can be intimidating for many viewers. I understand why Carruth spent so much time on this aspect. It's important to convince the audience to suspend its disbelief regarding time travel (always a tall order). It also sets the mood as the plot moves from science (the wonder of discovery) to ethics (the dilemma of using it). It's a nice transition, but that is perhaps overdone a bit at the beginning. Primer also makes good use of its very limited budget. The camera angles were consistently interesting and innovative; sometimes up close, sometimes through a window. The video quality is grainy, but rather than looking like a bad transfer to DVD, it gives the film a "home" or real-life quality that Hollywood can't capture. The biggest problem I had with Primer is the plot. It's rather convoluted and I don't feel like the film did enough at the beginning to really make the ending resonate with audiences. I'd say during the first hour the plot is discernible, if not exactly easy to comprehend. However, it's during the crucial last 20 minutes when it's not entirely clear who is doing what, when, how, and why. I watched those last 20 minutes twice and got the gist of it, but couldn't help thinking that there were too many loose threads. There is one plot twists that seems quite important and mysterious, but is never explained. Both characters go off in directions that don't seem to follow from what we know of them - or perhaps the movie doesn't tell us enough about them to understand their character arc. I think a bit more time developing the two main characters and their relationships beyond their time machine work would have helped. It's a shame because perhaps 10 more minutes of plot exposition (at 80 minutes, the film is actually pretty short) would have made this one of the top movies of the past decade

I was as confused as anyone else starting with "Act II" of this film.  I have this film figured out and have solved the mystery, me thinks.  No, it had nothing to do with the assorted websites and diagrams devoted to the paradoxes of time travel and "Weeble" creation (duplicates) pertaining to this film's uncharacteristically intelligent take on time travel.  I figured it out when I learned of Primer's humble microbudget of a $7000.  With this budget, nearly every penney had to have gone to Super 16 film stock and lab fees.  I thought this film was shot on video (which is fine) - looked it, and assumed so given its budget, but was perplexed by selective focus and scenes containing "bokeh" (generally film-only).  Often, long-term "labor of love" indies are shot sequentially or near sequentially, unlike big budget pics, which ironically are shot way out of sequence around location availability, sets, and actor schedules.  So, here's my theory - it's simple.  The film was shot sequentially, with the quite credible and well-handled "accidental invention of the time machine" sequences happening first as it was in the script. There was only so much film stock available - and once that was gone, that was it.  Too much precious film stock was used up early on - perhaps the actors couldn't do the 1:1(?) OR 2:1 tight shooting ratio, leaving not enough film left to explore the paradoxes in the 2nd half of the script.  This resulted in (in my opinion) an unbalanced film that spends too much time on the creation of the time machine, and not nearly enough exposition time in the second half to explain the paradoxes and duplicates - or even get into the deterioration of the relationship between Aaron and Abe.  The first half sucks you in, and the second half plays out like you have your DVD running at 4X speed - with just "snippets" of scenes wizzing by giving you a sketch of what's happening but no where near enough data to process to approach anything other than partial coherence at best (and most likely utter cluelessness...)  Now, what I've proposed is admittedly pure speculation but that's my guess.  Somehow, through clever editing or a "happy accident" - whatever, it all manages to work, and the net-net is a pretty compelling and certainly unique little indy time travel flick.  - Excellent natural performances, excellent time-travel concept, very good natural dialog, compositions are often outstanding (though not the best Super 16 transfer I've ever seen), acceptable audio and minimal but unobtrusive and appropriate score all add. Primer does somehow manage ultimately to work as a riddle - so in my speculation/opinion, hours were spent editing to salvage it from an incomperhensal, unreleasable, and unwatachable mess.  And while perhaps not hitting a "home run" in the process, hit a safe by a nose triple.  I watched it twice, and went to the 'Net to get "cheats".  Any film that manages to get me to do this earns a solid four stars in my book.  Primer is a flawed but compelling sci-fi film - a little overrated perhaps, but certainly worth your time.  It's a good time at the movies via an unusual route (incomprehension!) not travelled since the "starchild" ending of Kubrick's 2001.
